description:
I don't even know where to begin. Words can't even describe how much I enjoyed Guardino's. It was probably my favorite thing I ate during our West Coast vacation. 

My wife and I stopped here for lunch after we visited Alcatraz earlier that morning. We worked up an appetite and when we walked by Guardino's, we knew that's where we wanted to eat. We got a 1/2 Lobster, 1/2 Dungeness Crab roll and some clam chowder in a bread bowl. The seafood was extremely fresh and flavorful. I could have ate here for every meal and I would have been perfectly happy with that! I will always remember how amazing this lunch was and hope to return in the future for another one!
author: Christian C.

description:
This place was located on the corner of a busy intersection at Fisherman's Wharf. They sell a lot of different sandwiches that have lobster, lobster and crab, crab or shrimp. 

We decided to try the Shrimp sandwich. It was fairly priced. There was a lot of shrimp and it was fresh. You can taste that the shrimp was covered in mayo. The sourdough roll was ok.

Overall, I'd definitely recommend that you check this place out if you want to try one of their yummy sandwiches or other seafood items.
author: Lily Y.

description:
Stopped by here with a group of friends when we were strolling through Fishermans Wharf. The Lobster and Crab Roll caught our eye in their display fridge, so we grabbed one. It was at least 20 dollars for it but we thought it might be worth it with the amount of lobster and crab meat they put in it. 

When I got a hold of it, it looked beautiful! Quickly took a snap of it before my friends and I tried it. First impression was that it was just meh, nothing special. So, I thought maybe I just had a bad initial bite. I took a couple more bites and I honestly thought the bread was tough and the lobster and crab meat was mushy with too much mayo. Bread and mayo was all I really tasted! It was okay to eat, but honestly expensive for a decent lobster and crab roll. Makes a great picture though!
author: Anthony N.

description: I was playing tourist during clam chowder festivals Fisherman's Wharf. I had for a crab and shrimp sandwich. The sandwich was delicious. I also enjoyed the shrimp cocktail.
author: Juan V.

description:
What else is there to do when you're at fisherman's wharf? Get clam chowder of course! It is the location where the famous clam chowder is at! I do recommend though, if you are planning on getting clam chowder make sure to do some research. Don't just stop at one location and decide to go there cause it has a sign. Not all clam chowder is the same. 

This place is one of the biggest regret. The clam chowder was very sandy. The taste was lacking a bit. And there isn't any clams in it! The funniest part, with the lack of clams the chowder was very fishy. 

There is some yellow chunks on there, I think it's dried scallops. The texture is the same and with how fishy the chowder is...I totally think it is that. 

I do not recommend getting the chowder here.
author: Drew R.

description:
Clam chowder was kinda watered down..or maybe I just didn't get enough clams on mine? The bread bowl was good though.
Shrimp and Crab sandwich was just Ok, didn't really wowed me...it think it was a little over priced for the way it tasted.
I would just stick to the bread bowl and chowder!
author: Maricel J.

description:
Even if you have never been to Guardino's, you won't have a hard find time finding it. Just look for the food stalls around Fisherman's Wharf and find the one with the longest line. That's Guardino's!

Of course, they do sell clam chowder here but that's not the reason why we came here. The must have item here is the overstuffed crab and lobster salad sandwich!  Kind of pricey as we paid a whopping $21 for this sandwich. But with the generous amount of lobster they put in? It's so worth it! 

The lobster they put in that sandwich is the real thing, not the imitation ones. The sandwich is stuffed with big chunks of lobster that you would require you to use a fork to be able to eat it. They even put the lobster claws on top. Mixed with perfect amount of mayo - Oh, boy! It's just so good!
author: Cris I.

description:
If you come to San Francisco, you have to eat at Fisherman's Wharf. Guardino's is the first restaurant in the strip of seafood stands, as it's hard to choose which one to go to. The prices and appearances of the food are all about the same.

I tried the Rock Crab and Shrimp Sandwich ($9.75). There was a lot of crab and shrimp, but just as much mayonnaise. The bread roll is also a lot and dense too, so all in all it's quite filling. Make sure it hasn't been sitting there a while ... you never know.

Beware of the seagulls and birds if you are holding food, they attack in flocks! One will distract you, while the other will knock it out of your hand, and the others will swarm the ground for food.
author: Vincent H.

description:
Open early had Dungeness crab sandwich for my breakfast! Freshly made! The vendor was enthusiastic and friendly, answered all my questions and made and awesome recommendation. 

It was a great way to start the day, $21 for a sandwich and it was worth it! The Dungeness crab flavorful, the sourdough bread was fresh and soft, and you get a lot of crab meat. Had to use the fork given in order for me to actually bite the sandwich. 

My friend got the clam chowder on a sourdough bread and wow, that was good as well, a lot of clam meat and tasty.
author: Julie Ann I.

description: Seriously one of the best lobster sandwich I've ever had. Got one to share with my boyfriend and it was more than enough for the both of us. They were not stingy with the lobster and it was reasonably priced. Ate it so fast, didn't get a chance to take a picture of it.
author: Thoa H.

description:
I guess I forgot about my subpar chowder from 7 months ago because we ended up here again, lol!  A long-standing tradition my spouse and I have is to have some clam chowder while overlooking the bay.  That way, you get the full effects that go with Fisherman's Wharf - the crisp ocean breezes, seagull calls, the smell of wood & oil from the pier, and the view of Alcatraz.  Heaven for us!

Guardino's clam chowder is available in 3 sizes: Cup, pint and quart.  Being that we're a party of two and the cup size was too small, we got a quart and split it, which costs $5 less than two pints!  This time, the chowder tasted better; more creaminess and was served piping hot.  Most of all, props to the lady worker who went above and beyond my request for an empty bowl so we could make a split.  She gave us two empty bowls, oyster crackers and even bagged them up for us.  Thanks!!!!  Great service and with a smile.  

OVERALL:
Add those 2 stars back!
author: Vince N.

description:
Of the many options for crab rolls on the way to the pier in Fishermans wharf, this was the best decision I made all day. We scoped out each place for the best looking crab roll and while they all looked alright, the crab rolls at Guardino's made the others look like garbage. It was about $23 for a crab roll which may seem steep, but for the amount of crab you get it's totally worth it. They had way more crab than any other place around and it was to die for! The bread was also delicious (to be expected) and didn't hide the flavor of crab. 

If you're craving crab rolls or just want some seafood for a quick lunch, pick something up from Guardino's.
author: Cara H.

description: Biggest lobster portions for your buck. We came back there for seconds the next day! Fresh and tasty. You have to try it at least once. And clam chowder was delish too! Recommend!!!
author: Nadia M.

description:
I was one of the many tourists that were walking around Fisherman's Wharf with a clam chowder bread bowl in hand, trying to feed myself spoonfuls in between my steps

Not exactly sure why I chose this stand out of the line of chowder and seafood businesses but this one felt right. The seafood in the display case looked amazing and hopefully fresh. The price were almost all the same in this area but this was one of the lowest.

Straight to the point. Chowder was delicious, clammy just how I like it. No regrets at all not a single one

Oh and the guy in front of me bought a $20 lobster roll... so business must be good. But to  assure you, the chowder has the most reasonable price on the menu, right around $8
author: Deanne L.

description: This place has become an obsession! Saturday we got crab rolls with extra rolls and Sunday we treated ourselves to lobster rolls.. with extra rolls. Under normal circumstances, I try to eat as little bread as possible but the sourdough is so delicious, it would be absurd not to have it.
author: Katie G.

description: Looking for a lobster roll and there's looked the freshest.  $21 was steep for a street vendor but there was a ton of claw meat on top of the sandwich.  Once I got past the claw meat there was a mushy pile of crab and mayo...mostly mayo.  Tried but I had to toss the whole thing.
author: Brandi L.

description:
The Best crab sandwich on Fishermans wharf with an ice cold beer!
Nice soft sourdough roll filled with delicious, finger licking and over-loaded (a pound or more) with fresh Dungeness crab. Sooooo good!   
We had to buy one to take home with us.
Fantastic!!
author: Theresa T.

description:
I recommend coming here early so you get the fresh bread. You can pick and choose which exact sandwich you want so don't be afraid. We ordered from the stand right on the corner. Do be careful ordering in the afternoon! 

I don't recommend eating the sandwiches that have been exposed to the sun for a while! Look carefully! 

We always get the rock crab and shrimp roll! Ask for extra lemon because sometimes the mayonnaise can over power the sandwich. We went on a limb and ordered the lobster roll. Now it is $20 but we decided to try it for once. I was alright, I wouldn't say it's fine dining lobster but you do get what you paid for. All of the sandwiches are packed with seafood. We always come here when we're in town but next time I'd skip the lobster roll. You could get the basic sandwich (crab and shrimp) and your cravings should be satisfied! It's a must ordering food here when you're in town!
author: Kaleigh R.

description: Go here every time I come to sf. They are not salty. And it's sooo tasty. The bread bowl is so fresh. And must try. It's also cheap!
author: Suley Z.

description:
Their lobster roll was delicious!  Super stuffed, fresh tasting meat, chewy outside on the bread and soft in the middle. Surprisingly not soggy. 

At $21 price a little steep but would buy again when craving for a good lobster roll hits.  Great for on the go.
author: A T.

description: Then enture week we were in San Fran we ate here daily. The lobster rolls were so delicious. The people who worked there were so sweet. And there's soup in the bread bowl is on point. I love this place.  Every time we go to San Fran we always go here! Try it out you won't be sorry!
author: Stacy B.

description:
I really enjoyed my lobster/crab roll here. The service is fast and friendly. The are really really yummy! I only wish that the sourdough was toasted, but the amount of crab meat and lobster you get for about 20 bucks is darn good! They have other things on the menu such as crab sandwiches, clam chowder, salads, and other little seafood yummies, but my fav of course is the rolls. 

If back in the area I'll for sure be back to try something new. Probably won't be a cheat day, so can't splurge too much on the yummy goodness, but will figure some healthy ha ha alternative!
author: S S.

description:
WANNA GET VERBALLY ASSAULTED, LOOK NO FURTHER. Took a photo of the restaurant and a short-tempered​ bearded employee became angry to the point he came over the counter at out in street to try and fight me and destroy​ my camera, really professional. 

Avoid this place like cancer, food blows as does little hot-tempered employees. I mean it's a touristy area, you have no right to privacy.

This place blows, if you want good bread, good soup and not get assaulted go across the street to Boudin's. 

ZERO STARS.
author: Phuck Y.

description:
The lobster roll is AMAZZZIINNNGGGG!! We could eat here everyday for lunch. Well we wouldn't be able to afford it. We kinda did on our trip though. Two days in a row at $20.95. it has everything you need in a lobster roll: a roll, and lobster. The lobster has mayo and maybe butter, none of those vegetables that get in the way, but you get tons of lobster and every bite squeezes a bit out so you eventually need the fork they give you. There's even lobster claw meat on top, about 4 pieces. The roll is a sourdough, it's your average San Francisco-y bread it's sour and soft it's good. It's not buttered or toasted but it still works well.  
The sandwiches are pre-made and sitting in their display case, which I don't find a problem for a cold sandwich and I don't want to wait 15 minutes for them to make one.  
It's a small little stand, so there's no sitting area next to it, but it's easy enough to walk and eat, asking for an extra tray helps.  There's an area with benches and tables a few hundred feet away in front of the Musee Mecanique. Watch out for birds!
author: Adelio L.

description: We had a yummy lobster and crab roll from here. Couldn't resist when we saw other people with them and it was a pretty good price!!
author: Rowena B.

description:
I should've did some research on what goes into a crab/lobster roll.

Then I would've known that it's a crab/lobster salad sandwich. I like mayonnaise
author: Filiku M.

description: I don't know about you but I don't know many places where I can find a rock crab and shrimp stuffed hoagie for under $10!  This place has 'em and they are fresh. Seriously, they are made to order and they are amazing in price, portion and taste.  I like to come here for the chowder.  They also have huge lobster rolls and what not. You should check 'em out if you are ever in the area.  I doubt you will be disappointed.  During the busy parts of the day, it might be hard to get the attention of the vendors but once you have it, they'll definitely take good care of you.
author: Chris C.

description: We always stop here for chowder every time we visit SF. One of the best chowder since you taste the sea more than the cream.
author: Maricar D.

description: We had lunch here which is among the many cafes along the wharf.  The reason we stopped here was because of the chunk crab and lobster topped mayo salad sandwich.  It was an overstuffed salad roll topped with chunks of crab and lobster for $21.  Their clam chowder had bits of clam and vegs and was thick served inside a sourdough bread for $9.  They have beer and soda but no wine here.  We found wine next door.  Also, there is no seating so you either sit at the wharf entrance with the sea gulls overhead or around the side where there is shade.
author: Michele L.

description: If you want a good lobster roll/crab sandwich.. DO NOT EAT HERE!! I repeat DO NOT EAT HERE!! Not worth $22, barely any lobster in the lobster roll, all mayonnaise filling. For the lobster roll, they had like three good pieces sitting on top but looks are deceiving because right when my boyfriend was done eating those pieces... then came the mayo filling. It tasted so much just like straight up mayonnaise that he took a bite and threw it away. In the crab sandwhich, all mayonnaise filling as well& they have all the sandwiches pre made sitting in the fridge. So disappointed and waste of money:( we were really craving this too so we were pissssed lol we also had the clam chowder and that was ok. Barely any clams and tasted like it was straight out of a can. Btw, not trying to bash this place.. just my honest opinion! And don't want anyone else to have a bad experience when hungry lol!
author: Sue H.

description:
It's a little pricey, but the sandwich is 1/2lb of Dungeness crab piled high on a sour dough roll. While it has a light dressing, there is no need for additions or condiments, as the taste of the crab is so buttery and rich, that it really is its own flavour.

This is easily the best stall at Fisherman's Wharf, and they're open real early, if you're looking for a quick breakfast that, while not cheap, is very filling and extremely delicious.
author: Stevie D.

description: Me and my boyfriend are walking through pear 39and we found those guys, because we saw huge line in front of thiS place, I know about the traditional food at San Francisco pier it is clam chowder and lobster sandwich, we tried clam chowder last time when we visited this beautiful city, now we decided to try crab lobster sandwich. I like this sandwich,everything was good but, crab was too salty.
author: Ekaterina K.

description:
Really Fresh and Good Clam Chowder. I went online and google what must do or eat in San Fran and this place showed up. Its a food or market stand. Came here and got the Clam Chowder inside the bread cup. Unfortunately the bread was sourdough and I don't like sourdough. Darn I paid extra for nothing. Other than that the Chowder was really good. 

The lobster roll looked really good but for $20, I didn't end up getting it. I find it bit too pricey. 

There are no place to sit if you are looking for a place to sit down and eat. If you are lucky, you might find a bench outside or around the Fisherman wharf sign.

I highly recommend this place if you are visiting San Fran.

Also note that all restaurants in the area claim they have the best chowder. But only this one showed up when googling.
author: Denise W.

description: Solid street food. Service was excellent, fast, and super friendly instead of mindless and numb like other competitors. Clam chowder bread bowl is great here, especially if you prefer a thicker, creamier chowder with lots and lots of clams. Will choose this location over nearby competitors in the future.
author: Dan E.

description: Ughh. I got the shrimp sandwich and it was pure mayonnaise mixed with baby shrimp. Nothing else. I took one bite and threw the rest away. The sign that read "sorry no refunds" should have been a warning.
author: Mary D.

description: Simply amazing! Visited from Kansas City with my heart set on a lobster roll!! Thanks San Francisco for not disappointing!!
author: Shirley J.

description:
Loved the squid calamari 10/10 
You can get the fresh taste of the squid 
Could taste the marination and the dressing had lots of flavor. 
Tried that yesterday morning 

Today tried the clam chowder today
That was 3.5/5 it was good but lacked a flavor
author: Ruby P.

description: This food location is next to a bunch of other, just as loud and crowded ones that are almost exactly like it. But the food is always going to be tasty with pretty big portions. It a good spot to pick up everything you want for a meal and sit somewhere with a view in the wharf. Not too sure about quality though.
author: Arshan A.

description:
Still on NY time, we decided to take a long walk early in the morning instead of lazing about in bed. Guardino's was one of the few places that were open at 7am, and the friendly guy behind the counter explained that he started work that morning at 3 in the morning. I respect the hustle.

Dungeness crab sandwich was generously stacked high with large chunks of meat. Only drawback was that the bread was a bit too chewy and doughy, but not surprised since it came out of a fridge. The chowder was delicious, but a little too salty for my taste. 

Overall a pretty good choice if you're in the area at an ungodly morning hour.
author: Ann Y.

description:
I don't normally go to Fisherman's Wharf for crab.  But since I was in the area and with it being Dungeness Crab season, I had a craving for a good Crab Sandwich.  Pretty much knowing that the best place on the Wharf would be the Crab Stands, Guardino's was the first one I encountered and got my attention with their Crab Sandwiches on display.

The Crab Sandwich certainly was a beauty (http://bit.ly/1vGBSCa).  Sourdough roll STUFFED with crab, mayo, and topped with claw meat.  The crab was so goood!!  That's one thing you can guarantee around the Wharf is that the seafood is totally fresh.  The only thing that bothered me was the sourdough roll, which I'm not really a fan of, it was tough for me and by the time I finished my sandwich my jaw was a little sore.  I would've preferred something like a brioche roll like I've had at Sam's and The Lobsta Truck.  But overall, it was a solid sandwich.  The price for the sandwich that day was around $18, which may seem a lot, but not too bad considering that when it's not crab season, the price can be double that.

If you're around Fisherman's Wharf during crab season, definitely check out the Guardino's Crab Stand and try their Crab Sandwich.  You won't be disappointed!
author: Rodney H.

description: Owned and ran by Asian couple, you'll wonder at the name. A lot of people were in line for this little street store so we lined up as well. Hubby wants to try the clam chowder and I wanted to try the lobster roll. Both proved to be excellent choices! They're pricey but they're worth it! I love the food, this place and the sweet man who always asks as about our dining experience.
author: Eileen L.

description: We had the lobster roll. It was 21$ for one lobster roll but it did not disappoint. I kept saying "omg this is so delicious" after every bite. It was a massive amount of claw meat on a nice sourdough bun. The only reason it's not a 5 star review is that the guy touched his nose then touched the food with bare hands and didn't wear gloves. Yes I'm a little bit of a germ-a-phobe.
author: Lorraine S.

description:
Yelp's 365 Review Challenge 2014 #155 - #365

This place is huge and located right by the wharf, walking distance to the dock and the boardwalk. There's an area where they make fresh sourdough bread and a machine that transfers the dough to the prepping area. It was fun to watch them made fresh San Franciscan sourdough bread. 

We were visiting San Francisco and were walking by Guardino's and decided to have a taste of San Francisco. I ordered the infamous Clam Chowder and it was chewy and the texture was so smooth. Tasting the clams was a real treat giving it that San Francisco feel. 

Next time I'll try more off the menu, maybe some seafood or sandwhichs. We were in a hurry to view the rest of the wharf, so I will take note of Guardino's.
author: Paul B.

description: Guardino's is the only place we go for a piping hot clam chowder sourdough bread-bowl. It's our first stop after getting off the trolley on a cold December morning during our annual treks to SF. We've tried the chowder at other restaurants, but nothing else comes even close!
author: Eglin A.

description: Worst lobster roll I have ever had, nice people but I ended up throwing the entire thing in the trash. Save yourself $20 bucks.
author: Robert A.

description: My sister came to town and decided that she wanted to visit fisherman's warf. She had a craving for a lobster roll. One of the only places that had it was here.  $20.95 you would expect for it to be a tasty venture.  But unfortunately it was a cold mess. Too much mayonnaise that you couldn't taste the lobster, child tough sourdough bread that seems to have never been toasted.  I would not recommend this place.
author: David K.

description: Got the lobster roll and felt there was too much mayo used. The bread was not toasted and was cold.
author: Cindy H.

description: It was really delicious. We got the clam chowder bread bowl and the lobster roll. Both were very filling. The staff were friendly even with the amount of people standing by and ordering. A must try in my opinion.
author: Erica M.

description:
This place is a hole in the wall. The clam chowder was fantastic. Ate at Bubba Gumps for dinner. Will do a review for that place after.

Looking for some great seafood for a pretty good price, stop by here. Again, small place with really good food for you seafood lovers. Clam chowder for me.
author: Mike M.

description: We picked up a lobster roll from here and it was huge! The lobster roll of my dreams. The kind that you dream about when you leave the city. Great stuff. Would definitely come back.
author: Shelly S.

description:
I have walked by this row of sandwich stores in the past a few times but I forget every time I'm in the area because I always want a sandwich but find myself to be too full. NOT THIS TIME.

Wasn't sure what to order but ultimately chose the Rock Crab and Shrimp sammy for $9ish bucks. The sandwich is split in half with the two meats on either side so why not basically try two halves of a sandwich?

Pretty A-okay/meh sandwich. The fillings were not terrible but was missing a lot of flavor and had more mayo than necessary for me. Rock Crab is not as juicy as other kinds of crab so it was not as satisfying as I thought. The shrimp is eh. The bread is a sourdough roll but COLD because they pull the sandwiches from the display case. Not sure if they can make a fresh one for you or if they can toast stuff but I wish I had asked but it didn't occur to me at the time.

Overall.......glad I tried it but not getting it again. May come back to get the lobster rolls.
author: Sofia R.

description:
Was really fun visiting Fisherman's Wharf and seeing all the eatery stands outside. Was in the mood for lobster roll and sourdough bowl of clam chowder. Got both at Guardino's and both were excellent. The lobster roll was typical lobster in bun but top was packed with lobster meat ($20). The clam chowder was excellent as well ($7). Really enjoyed both although first time I had sourdough I would prefer something else but the bread was really good in terms of chewy texture. Perfect for sopping up the clam chowder. Too bad don't live in SF or would be going to eat at Fisherman's Wharf all the time.

Only issue is finding a place to actually eat the food. We were lucky to have room right at Guardino's on their counter but if a ton of people, could be problematic.
author: Chris L.

description:
Ordered at Guardino's---
I was very excited to come here since I really love seafood, especially crabs and oysters. But I am very disappointed with my orders. I ordered clam chowder, lobsters claws cocktail and the lobster sandwich. 
Lobster claws are fresh but quite rubbery in texture. Lobster sandwich is bad. It's like shredded lobster with some chunks of claws mixed with tons of mayo and lacks flavor. Bread is just tough. 
Clam chowder so far is the best tasting of all. Not so thick nor thin in consistency and the flavor is just right. It's enjoyable to eat even when with the fairly hot weather.
Might go back for the clam chowder.
Vendors are very delightful!
author: Kam V.

description: $8 clam chowder. The clam chowder taste was mediocre, you can taste the distinct seafood flavor, BUT when I saw them pour the soup into my bread bowl, they threw in LARGE chunks of bread in with the soup. When I found a place to sit and eat the soup, you can see the large chunks of bread that became a little smaller after soaking up the clam chowder. They should not be doing this, hence the low ratings. I will definitely try a different clam chowder shop next time I am in the area since there are 10+ right on that street alone.
author: Andrew S.

description: For a sidewalk stand, this place rocks. You should try a crab sandwich. It may seem pricey, but  it is really enough crab for two people. The perfect meal to take out on the wharf and eat while smelling the salt air and watching street performers. It's family-owned and operated since 1908 - my son knows one of the Guardinos from Lincoln High.
author: Michael R.

description: In San Francisco at the Fisherman's Warf and clam chowder was a MUST! Saw this place with a large group of people ordering so figured I'd give it a try. I got the clam chowder in the Sourdough bowl. Price was about average in the surrounding places. Honestly though the clam chowder would have been the only thing I'd order there. Everything else was crazy expensive. The clam chowder was pretty darn good though. The sourdough bowl was just alright. When eaten with the clam chowder was good but after by itself not do much. Pretty much just tossed it. I'd go there again but just get a regular bowl.
author: Kristofer D.

description:
visited the beautiful San Francisco from SoCal and wanted to have a quick chowder bowl along the pier and this place wasn't a let down! 

my friends and I all ordered a chowder bowl and it was ready in about 5 minutes. the soup was already made and the bread bowls were already cut out. the taste was very delicious. it wasn't salty as I thought, which I liked. I topped it off with some black pepper and crackers~ which made it extra delicious. finished the chowder bowl in about 15 mins and it was honestly satisfying. it was about $7 and some change for one :3
author: Monica M.

description:
My wife and I walked to Fisherman's Wharf from our nearby hotel.  We chose Guardino's to experience the Chowder Breadbowl.  We also ordered the Rock Crab and Shrimp Sandwich.  The service was fast.  However the sandwich was pre-prepared and fetched from the refrigerated glass case.  The counter staff were rushed and surly.  No personality whatsoever.

The chowder was hot.  It was just OK.  I'm not sure if this is made from scratch, but it seemed to be from a can.  Bland and not so special.  The sandwich was just OK.  The best part of the meal was the bread.  It was awesome!  And the view.  We sat on the tiered wall next to the Fisherman's Wharf sign.

I would recommend you trying another place!
author: Geo P.

description:
We were looking for a quick snack... and knew all these stands were tourist traps.  We chose Guardino's because it had the longest line. 

Super fast service, but $6 went down the drain pretty quickly. Bread bowl was unimpressive and tasted like it had been sitting around for a while. Chowder was served lukewarm and seemed like it was out of a can (probably true). A combination of the two made a disappointing snack. 

Skip the stands and head over to Boudin. It's popular and hyped up because it's actually good!

--
PHOTO: 
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=wD7tKKCL6p9sDuYpyTZG6g&userid=Vx-l5rI0xAiN4SeBonrgkw
author: Kevin L.

description:
Hit up my hubby's favorite spot in SF to get some good clam chowder!

It was great, flavor was on point, and that sourdough! Mmmmmm

Doesn't get much better than this! Decently priced. Great spot in the Fisherman's Wharf area. I'd return for more!
author: L T.

description: Happy kind and very welcoming people who love working and serving people. The food is amazing and so fresh. Keep up the good work and continue to make and serve good food. Thank you mokan for the lobster, fresh crab meat and seafood chowder. Amaze balls.. we will be back...
author: Ismael A.

description: We absolutely loved this place!  The lobster rolls were some of the best we've had. The seafood bowls made for a great snack, and the clam chowder was delish. This was another place we were repeat customers. Service was quick!
author: Jill F.

description:
Ordered the Lobster roll .. 19.95 

Now I will Tastify 

No complaints about the cost
Lobster salad was bland 
The bread was tough, cold, and boring 
(I had to rip at the bread to get a piece off) 
Which made lobster salad squeeze out

Question to ponder :

How can you be in an area that is known for amazing bread and serve those rolls .. Right across the street is a HUGE bakery making great bread .. Just sayin .   
The Roll ..IS HALF THE SANDWICH.. 
Especially in a Lobster ROLL 
RIGHT ?? At least it is for me .. 

Anyway .. I always ask myself one question after I eat somewhere .. 
Will I return ? My answer has two letters in it
author: Tom S.

description:
in my opinion, THIS is the only place to get your clam chowder bread bowl in fisherman's wharf. sure, you can get one on every corner in a 10 mile radius...but there is something about the no frills street stand experience in the heart of the fish market. legit.

probabaly a lot of fish snobbery going on but i think this is the best clam chowder in town! so creamy and delicious with lots of clams and potatoes (probably more a focus for this russian girl). great price for portion.
author: Heather W.

description: Avoid! Rats everywhere. I got horrible food poisoning and have never been so sick. When I called to tell them, they were horrible to me. This place should be condemned and I am reporting to the Dept of health.
author: Lee S J.

description: I ordered a shrimp and crab cup for $10.25 and thought is was good.  I like that Guardino's gives customers cocktail sauce and melted butter.
author: E D.

description:
Great station.   The crab is perfectly prepared and the ambiance of eating and enjoying a beer on the sidewalk is unique.   The butter has a perfect hint of garlic.   The bread bowl clam chowder is also a hit.   Crab has been $12.95/pound forever so one whole crab is just about $20 and worth the experience.   You'll have to move through the heavy tourist crowds and put up with the occasional onlooker that is intrigued by eating curbside or trying to figure out how to eat a crab top to bottom. 
BIG HINT... save a couple of lemon wedges to rub on your fingers/hands when your done.  You don't want your hands to smell like seafood all day... unless that's your thing.
author: Rome B.

description:
Guardino's, touted to have been there since 1908, has obviously lost the family recipe for clam chowder. If you have ever in your life had real New England Clam Chowder, you will spit this out. Or if you are really hungry, you will chalk it up to a poor choice and finish the tiny bowl not worth its price or even half of it. The consistency is way too watery, the clams (if you can find them) have to be canned and there is no attention to the actual flavor whatsoever.

When there are four chowder spots staring you in the face and you have never even been down to Fisherman's Wharf, I guess it's easiest to just choose the first one in line. Unfortunately, that was not the best method for making the choice. They give you oyster crackers or offer it in a bread bowl for a reason - these products soak up the water in the bowl and let you enjoy the cracker or bread, thereby masking the very poor excuse for a bowl of chowder.

We saw someone getting crabs though and they looked fresh. I hope he was happy.
author: Jonathan G.

description: Don't be fooled by all of the yummy crab sandwiches in the window. We ordered a shrimp and crab sandwich and both were super super salty. The bread was tough. It was not worth the $10. I'm glad we didn't splurge for the $16 dungeness crab!
author: Kristine N.

description:
On any given day, and even any given time of day, some of these wharf fish stands will have food that looks mediocre to you, and sometimes they will have something that jumps out at you & screams, you must eat this! Maybe the fish has been sitting out for a bit, or maybe brisk business means they're continually reloading the displays with something just prepared.

Today, walking past Guardino's, the lobster roll called to me. It was tasty. I think I like the crab rolls better at the various wharf stands, especially at their dramatically lower price, but I'm glad I got it, it was quite good.

I suggest you only buy one food item at a time. It's easy to go back & get a second item, possibly from a different vendor. The fewer items you're carrying, the easier it is to negotiate your way through the crowds to find a place to enjoy your food. If you only have one item it's easy to hold it while eating, if you can't find counter space.

The street-facing side of the booth has a metal counter, a luxury to sit your drink down while you stuff your face with lobster & sourdough bread. Tourists & locals alike walk haltingly along Taylor Street, to look at the menus, the crabs, & to see if what you're eating looks good. Smells of fish & cool ocean breezes permeate your nostrils. The din of traffic, the MUNI street car, tourists, happy and/or screaming children, rap from boom boxes and the gold and silver painted robot-men who move mechanically to the beat, seagulls, the light carnival soundtrack emanating from Musee Mecanique, and street musicians butchering your favorite tunes all collide for your attention.

Eating outside amongst crowds isn't everybody's cup of tea. I like it because when I'm with friends or family, I love a good restaurant. But sometimes I just want a few different small tastes, and when I'm in the mood for fish, Pier 43 is a great destination.

- Adam
author: Adam M.

description: not bad.  Came here for a pint of clam chowder and lobster roll as a late night snack.  Both were fresh and very tasty.   This is in a tourist area so prices are high as expected.  Would definitely come again if in the area.
author: Si C.

description: service was okay, small shack set up on the corner. the chowder was all right.. had too many clam chunks and very watery could use some more seasoning
author: Michelle S.

description: My sister and I stopped here to share a Dungeness crab sandwich.  We decided it was just ok.  We did like that the Dungeness crab sandwich had bigger chunks of crab than the rock crab sandwich.  Also, the chucks of claw meet on top were nice too. However, the sandwich was very mayonnaise-ey and hard to eat given the very firm and chewy roll it was served on.  The sandwich was served with a lemon wedge so we used the acidic lemon juice to balance out the fat of the mayo a little better.  It was fine but not something  I'd crave. I would probably rate my experience with only two stars except I know that growing up on the waters of the Chesapeake Bah my standards for seafood are unintentionally high.
author: Courtney K.

description:
I visited this place at their walk up counter for a quick bite to eat. I have to say, for the price, you're really getting some pretty good food.

I had the combo sandwich (crab & shrimp) and a cup of clam chowder. I was a little nervous about the sandwich, it's pre-made and sitting in their fridge. It looked like an overly mayonnaised mess on a roll. It was surprisingly good. The seafood flavors came through fresh and clean and the roll was a nice chewy sourdough. I was afraid since it was premade it would be complete mush, but it was quite the opposite. It was also a pretty big serving for $8, a very reasonably sized lunch meal for me.

The chowder was good, but not spectacular. I did like that it had a lot of potato in it, but the flavor wasn't anything more than average for fresh clam chowder. $5 for a decent size cup and some crackers is pretty hard to beat and it was piping hot.

Highly recommended for a quite bite of good, fresh seafood. I'll return here when my stomach rumbles again in this area.
author: Matt R.

description:
First station on the block yet it was completely dead...hm wonder why?
Service guy was rude and had an off putting attitude.  Compared to the rest of the stations- seafood did not look fresh and looked as if it had been sitting around for a long time without getting replaced.

Pass.
author: J C.

description: I'm not very picky with my clam chowder. I love clams and often eat them straight from the can. So I was happy when my clam chowder bread bowl had lots of clams in it. Unfortunately, it was barely dug out so it was mostly bread with maybe a cup of chowder. Perhaps I got a bad bowl. It was good while it lasted, which wasn't long. A few birds gave me 'the eye' when I threw all the extra bread away - next time I'm on the wharf I'll probably give another place a try, even though my gaze usually catches Guardino's first.
author: Amy S.

description: I love crab but this wasn't the season and the crab just wasn't as good as I hoped.
author: Anne Marie S.

description: Totally and utterly unimpressed! I'm surprised that so many Yelpers said this was one of the better clam chowder stands because honestly, the soup tasted like a can of freaking Progresso!!! There was a very odd fishy flavor, which still makes me cringe, thinking about it! Even the bread bowl couldn't save the soup because it wasn't even special bread, ugh! This definitely does NOT compare to Pike's Place Chowder in Seattle, which is THE best chowder I've ever, ever, ever had! This place sucks!!!!
author: Nancy T.

description:
They're a decent place for a bread bowl in Fisherman's Wharf area. Nothing special, but most of the places aren't in my opinion. 

The soup tasted like Progresso, but I was just buying one so my cousin visiting from China could see what a SF Bread Bowl was. The lady serving me was really nice, and there was no wait time. However, that also means that my soup had probably been sitting around for a while...
author: June C.

description:
Being an SF native, coming here was the first time I ever had a Seafood combo sourdough sandwich . Typically, I avoid ALL tourist traps in the city, especially if I have to drive to Fishermen's Wharf/Pier 39, but this place was a pleasant surprise that made the trip out worth it (that and seeing socal friends from college!)

This place is a fun mom and pop owned stall; both are very friendly and can be seen lovingly bickering with one another at rare moments. I had the seafood combo sandwich , which was half shrimp and half tuna on a sourdough bun with a lemon wedge.  Very flavorful and the tastes mixed and blended together smoothly like buttaaa. My bf got an order of the oysters, which he enjoyed very much as well. Each piece was meaty and they gave plenty.

Very enjoyable experience and glad I got to eat something local at the wharf.
author: Ken T.

description:
I ate a couple of these little crab stands on the warf over a 1 week period.  Guardino's was the best.  Much of it is  due to the rotation of the food. I ate at The Crab Station next to Guardion's also but Guardino's did a better job cleaning the crab and were far friendlier.  
Crab tasted great was clean very well, I ate everything but the shell. 
The crab and lobster are at market price so they will weigh it and let you know the price up front. 

Watch out for the gulls, they will dive bomb you for your food.  If you're eating at the stand it can get crowded so you'll have to look for a place to eat your food.  This is no fine dining, but it is really good food. 

I can't wait to come back.
author: Paul G.

description:
I am addicted to their crab sandwiches.  However, in 2005 or so there used to be a guy working here, or on a nearby stand who was a big white guy and he used to always thrown in a few shrimp.  I miss that guy.  I guess I used to go here a lot more often.

Today when I went to Guardino's my crab sandwich was $6.95 and there was no tax.  For me that's a good deal.  I was full.  I suggest you get one and split it with a friend for a great snack.

I also like their clam chowder in a bread bowl, but I don't like that it's from a can (with non-dairy creamer in it).  So minus one star for that, even though it is delicious.  i would rather pay $2 extra for fresh chowder.
author: Cynthia B.

description: A San Francisco staple is what I was told. Great fresh seafood to munch on while walking around the wharf. Service was quick and the food lived up to its reputation. I will stop by next time I'm in town.
author: Nicole D.

description:
Not the best chowder I had at Fisherman's Wharf. 

Had the classic bread bowl which was probably around $10. I initially thought the chowder was too watery but it slowly grew on it. Still can't say it was the best I've had but it was definitely much needed on a super cold & windy day on the wharf. 

Probably not going to choose this stand in the future. There are plenty of options in this area and they are all about the same price, it's just about finding the chowder that suits you best.
author: Vanessa F.

description: The clam chowder here was okay and nothing too special.  The big downer here is that there was no where to sit down.  All the vendors had a small area to sit down.  I had to go with my friends and find a random spot near the pier to put the food on the platform like a table.
author: Vijay R.

description: Total rip off.  Get the chowder breadbowl, its a piece of shitty sourdough with a few tablespoons of hot potato cream.
author: alex c.

description: Well if you want to push through the crowd on the corner to get a over priced what looks like crab and mayo sandwich, this is your place. My son and husband had a crab sandwich and they said it was better than it looked. I got a hotdog!
author: Kori M.

description:
To be honest, the rest of this review would be more praiseful if I had not been attacked TWICE by seagulls who wanted a piece of my "crab" sandwich. After trying to scoop out the dents made by bird beaks, I decided not to pit my immune system against whatever nascent viruses they had left behind. So, I can only review the sandwich based on looks (bread: well-shaped, crab: white shavings of something compacted into an unappetizing loaf). It made a satisfying thud when I tossed it into the garbage. 

My wife knows how I get when I'm hungry, so she happily shared her clam chowder bowl. It was warm and the bread was spongy and absorbent, perfect for eating with. 

So, if you want clam chowder from the first stand on the block, go for it, but skip the crab sandwich, and keep one eye on the skies if you decide to go out in the open air.
author: Brigham B.

description:
Seafood festivities will definitely occur once you hit Guardinos! They have everything from cups of calamari to lobster salad sandwiches. It's fresh, flavorful and a lot of fun. My boyfriend (of 12 years) and I decided to partake in the "Night Street Food" experience and Guardinos was one of our stops. We tried the mussels, crab, calamari and the lobster claw. The calamari was marinated in a balsamic vinaigrette sauce. The lobster claw meat was moist and the crab legs tasted just like the ocean. 

I gave this place 4 stars because when you visit them on Friday and Saturday nights, the crowd on Fisherman's Wharf is very large and you may feel like that you're about to get robbed but SF is a mini NY so anyone visiting the city must always be on alert for those type of things. All in all, this place is definite "Must Go"!!
author: Iyani I.

description:
My first stop in my self styled four stop lunch tour of the outdoor stands of Taylor Street.

Had a bowl of the clam chowder. Creamy and thick with clams. Good stuff.
author: Gregory C.

description: I've had better clam chowder and bread. Should've just walked over to Boudin. But the staff was nice.
author: Hayden P.

description:
DO NOT get the clam chowder in sourdough bowl from here, it was more like a clam chowder flavored sourdough.
The size of the bread bowl was normal, but you don't get much clam chowder in it because the bread was barely cut out. Only a few sips and then you are left with only a loaf of sourdough.
author: Frank W.

description: Size is pretty big. It does seem a bit watery. If you are in a rush it's probably faster than other places. The staff is nice.
author: Will S.

description: First time I had clam chowder in Fisher's Wharf and choose this one.  It was very hot, not too much potato, lots of clam, very tasty.  The guy feel up the pint cup to the top and the lady give me two extra spoon without me asking.  Very observing.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Quite frankly the reviews in here complimenting the Clam Chowder using metrics like "even better than Progresso!" mean that this place is rated higher than it should be for people that are really serious (call me picky! I am definitely picky in this regard) about their clam chowder.

Canned clam chowder is almost consistently terrible, and Guardino's serves up a bowl that is not much better. Perhaps it's the economy, perhaps they're cutting costs, and it makes sense that their clam chowder is the cheapest out of all the stalls on this corner. Either way this chowder was watery and not particularly flavorful. It was also pretty sparse on the potatoes if you are into that. They did have enough clams but at this rate that is a compliment you'd only hear in recession.

Pro tip: Don't buy it in a bread bowl. If you really must, do yourself a favor and buy a cup of chowder and a separate bread bowl (for $2) and pour that in. The amount of chowder you get inside a bread bowl is a universal ripoff.


To reinforce some of the reviews mentioning how good Guardino's USED to be, I DO recall all the stands being universally better a couple years ago. This drop in quality could be easily attributed to the recession.
author: Kenny W.

description:
We had a list of five things to do in San Francisco and trying Guardino's clam chowder in a bread bowl was number two.  Approaching this small hole-in-the-wall on the pier, my expectations grew as I searched and searched for the end of the line.  "Yep, this is THE clam chowder place."

The overwhelming stench of lifeless sea creatures and overcrowding of brain dead tourists made the wait agonizing, but my expectations gave me the strength to hold my ground.  

Finally, my time has come.  I peeked over the countertop to tell the man I would like their clam chowder in a bread bowl, of course.  His eyes grew saddened.  "We are out of bread."  My eyes grew saddened, "You're out of bread?  You can't tell an Italian you're out of bread!   And this is San Francisco!  That's like Gilroy running out of garlic, or Idaho running out of potatoes, or Florida... This is number two on my list!"  Tragedy.  The man apologized, but I suggested he tell the mile long line behind his small counter that they were out of bread bowls.  He didn't.

So, I settled for a small white paper cup of clam chowder and walked away, breadless.  As I made my way through the crowds, it was as if everyone had a steaming hot, crispy sour bread bowl with creamy clam chowder dripping over the sides, except me.  Some glared at me like I was on the South Beach diet, too good for the San Francisco sourdough.  I wanted to yell, "They ran out, okay?!"  

I found a less disgusting place on the sidewalk to sit and began sipping on my Guardino's paper cup of clam chowder.  And, it was really, really good.  Creamy, clammy, salty, chunky but not too chunky.  Even with a bad attitude, it was perfect.  As the sorrow of my breadless chowder began to subside, suddenly someone threw change at me, "Go get a bread bowl for God's sakes!"  

(No, not really.)
author: Erin B.

description: Solid crab chowder. I didn't get the bread bowl because I knew I wouldn't eat it, and I was stuffed after my 8 oz. cup plus oyster crackers, so it was a good decision. There are lots of chowder options around here, and I can't say whether this was better than others, but I liked it. Grab a seat at a picnic table by the water and enjoy the view while you eat!
author: Monica D.

description: Currently their prices are $5.95lb for small and $10.95lb for the large crabs. The small ones weigh in about a good 2lbs uncooked. They are the cheapest of all the stalls, the only problem is finding a place to sit down and eat..
author: M C.

description:
I've always been an advocate for the small mom-and-pop places as supposed to the big corporate gorilla. Guardino's is a perfect example of that. Conveniently located in my favorite city's fisherman's wharf. For tourists visiting the fisherman's wharf, make sure you go past the big Boudin's that boasts original San Francisco Clam Chowder, Guardino's is only a few steps away. Guardino's is the mom-and-pop compared to the Boudin's which is the big corporate gorilla. Dont get me wrong, Boudin's has good clam chowder but if you want authentic San Francisco taste go to Guardino's.

The clam chowder spells San Francisco all over it. You can either get it in a styrofome cup or in a sour dough bread bowl. From my personal experience, you can never go wrong with the sourdough bread bowl, it just authenticates the dish altogether. The calamari is not bad either, but I would skip it.

The downside of going to this small mom-and-pop is that there are no tables or chairs to eat your food. You can either go on the few public benches or by the monument thingy and have a seat. Trust me, you do not want to be eating your chowder standing up with it on one hand and the spoon in the other. It just doesn't work. 

Becareful of the seagulls, THEY WILL JACK YOUR FOOD RIGHT FROM YOUR HAND. I know this from personal experience. After we have devoured our chowders, my girlfriend wanted to the try the calamari, so I went across the way to get some. On my way back to the monument thingy where we were situated, a seagull came and jacked a few calamaris from my open tray. That was comedy, but beware since the bird ruined our calamari and I had to get another tray and cautiously cover it with my hand as I cross. 

This place will be a definite stop for me again next time I am in the Bay Area, hell I might even move there just for the chowder! Yes, its THAT good.
author: jay v.

description: Grabbed a lobster roll on the go. It was pretty good. I munched away as I walked down the piers. $18 something. It was pretty pricey.
author: Jenn R.

description: I dont know what all the bad reviews are about I have been here twice and both times I got served by the same person we remembered each other and I got served the exact same tasting food I take my hat off to businesses that don't change when the times change this is awesome I hope that they stay here for many moons to come check it out They have my favorite bread bowls bar none they exceed the expectations of something just so simple
author: Justin H.

description: Excellent fresh whole crab. Expensive but you're on the wharf. The clam chowder was good but so are most of the neighbor shops. Good service.
author: Chris B.

description: We were walking around San Francisco in the wharf district.  We asked a doorman at a fancy hotel a street over, where's a good place to get clam chowder or a crab sandwich on the street.   He said this place.  So we went.   We got the clam chowder in the bread bowl.  It was noisy what with the seagulls and the crowd, and the guy yelling about this and that, but we loved it.  The clam chowder was good.  The bread was good.  The drink was cold.  It was memorable.  Don't change a thing, Guardino's.
author: Steve M.

description:
My original review is here... http://www.yelp.com/biz/fishermans-wharf-chowder-and-crab-sidewalk-stands-san-francisco#hrid:W0qRA0ghhQAlqgbvqdixuw before I figured out the names of the stalls

1 - (Guardino's) I had a total of 2 crabs here. This was the cheapest of them all this labor day weekend at $10.95 a lb. But be sure to choose the ones that were not at the bottom soaking up water (more weight ya' know). The first crab was awesome! We picked it, the guy cleaned it, opened it, and boiled it. I was brought up to like the insides of the shell ( I know many people discard it and I tell you it's a waste!!!) :D 
Their "Kraft" marinara sauce was a no-go for us, it tasted odd. But crab and lemon.. YUMM!! 

I sent the bf down there the next morning for a crab (CRAB FOR BREAKFAST!! :D). He ordered it to-go straight up expecting that the same guy would do the same as the day before and walked off in search of calamari since this stall hadn't started making them yet. He came back to a wrapped up cold crab. It turns out that the guy hadn't boiled it or gotten rid of the gills. Maybe that's what they do when you tell them to wrap it to-go? Not sure. So this time I had a cold crab and had to open the main shell myself. No big deal I can do it myself. 
Although, the boiled one did taste better.
author: Heidi C.

description:
I had been REALLY wanting one of their crab/shrimp salad sandwiches for a long time, so after scouring the other stands comparing the price:selection ratio, and a few weeks of making the want even stronger, I decided to try it out today. Yeah, clam chowdah is fantastic and I've never had a bad bowl of it (nor can I really taste the difference), but for this I was diggin on the sandwich. It was fresh, tasty, exactly what I had wanted, and paired with an All-Natural Mango Snapple, it was the perfect late lunch. Even the little bits of crab shell in it; it just proved that it was real crab and not shredded and dyed white fish.

And in Fisherman's Wharf with the smell of the bay and all the cool ass boats chillin in the background, I'd gladly give up $9.50 for this little meal.
author: Jackie T.

description: The location and experience can't be beat.  Authentic clam chowder steaming hot in a delicious bread bowl right in the heart of Fisherman's Wharf.  However, the clam chowder had barely any clams, and you can find more flavorful chowders at other places.  But regardless you still have to get one from this spot anytime you visit Fisherman's Wharf.  Just make sure to get a second one somewhere else.
author: Kasey O.

description: Definitely get the crab sandwich, dungeonness crab, and clam chowder bread bowl!!!   Great food for great price!   but very crowded so you might have a hard time finding a place to eat.  My friend and I walked over to the water area where there are benches w/ bunch of seagulls.  Keep on the lookout for those birds while eating :)
author: Monica W.

description:
The final destination of this crustacean was inside a burrito. And my stomach. Crab might not have been happy, but I was.

Portions seemed a little smaller than their neighbors, but quality just as good.
author: Jason B.

description:
We went to Guardino's to try the crabs, as we are from France this is really cool to have one on the pier in SF!! We went to this little place call Scoma's first but it was too expensive and fency as we just want a quick lunch!!
We found Guardino's on the pier, the lady who took care of ourselves first had an headphones on her ears so I don't really know if she was reading on our lips or if it was just a hipster things!!!
The second man was really rude as he listened to our bad french accent!! we took a combo of crabs, shrimps and lobster fot $9.. it was really small and the most we have inside was tiny tiny shrimps not fresh... The Clam soup was ok, the sandwiches full of mayonnaise... not really tasty!!I think you have better place to take food in this area!!!

Audrey
Paris
author: AUdrey B.

description:
Seeing how it's located right on Fisherman's Wharf, I'd have expected a much better seafood from this booth.  We got a bread bowl filled with clam chowder, and added on a cooked crab to snack on.  The crabs are available for purchase by the pound, then they cook them up quickly for you before handing you some dipping sauce and lemon to go with it.

The chowder was okay, but not great.  It tasted like a big batch of canned soup - but I suppose you can't expect too much from a small booth like that.  What turned me off from this place was the fact that the bread bowl was cut so as to really rip you off.  They removed just the top portion of bread, didn't hull it out at all, and filled it with soup so it looked like it was overflowing.  I was pretty excited with the portion until I stuck my spoon into it, and instantly hit bread.  Big disappointment.

The crab?  Old.  Come on, this is on a WHARF, how do you sell old crabs?  Might have been the fault of the fisherman, might have been the supplier, who knows?  But really, I don't go to a wharf and expect anything but the freshest of supplies.

This place is mediocre at best, from my experience.
author: Garrett P.

description: I just couldn't leave San Francisco without getting the obligatory clam chowder in a sourdough bread bowl.  On my way back to my cousins' apartment, I decided to get a bowl from this place.  It was as good as I expected.  Nothing spectacular, but it satisfied my appetite.  At $5.50 per bowl, you can't go wrong.
author: Paolo D.

description: The food was a little overpriced, but the food was good.  The people running the show were super friendly and stopped what they were doing to get my giant dog some water, without me even asking. 5 stars for service, 4 for price (comparable businesses were about a buck cheaper), and 5 stars for domestic beer prices.
author: Paul K.

description:
As I was having one of the most delicious clam chowders ever (better than Progresso even), I was thinking about writing this review. But what also crossed my mind was: What if I went on and on about this delicious clam chowder w/ lots of potatoes and clams, and it turned out to be canned? Wouldn't I look like an IDIOT!? 

Well, turns out that this stuff is canned but with a few ingredients added. Just great... You could've tricked us all! But its okay, cause I still liked it! $4.88 for a small little cup, just the wharf's price. I'd prefer this clam chowder over Sabella's anyday.

One thing that really bugged me though was that the guy working there had already stuck the plastic spoon into my soup, since the majority of customers do eat it right away. I had to ask for the lid because I wanted to take it back to work instead of sit in the middle of the wharf (its not like its the nicer Embarcadero area by the Ferries). So he took out the spoon, put on the lid, placed the spoon back into the tray and asked if I wanted a bag. I said yes, so he placed that whole thing inside the bag and put a couple of pieces of napkins in there, WITH the DIPPED SPOON still there! Of course, I took it out once I got to work and there was a little mess.

But, he did acknowledge my presence when I walked by the place and asked if I wanted clam chowder w/ bread bowl. He seemed nice. But the dude over at Sabella's is WAY more generous.
author: Elaine H.

description: After spending time walking around union square my stomach was grumbling.  I didn't want to leave without some good 'ol New England clam chowder!! I had it in a bread bowel of course and finished it in no time. My boyfriend and I would like to come back and next time get some prawns and shrimp as well. It was the perfect ending to a day in the city!!!
author: Anosha S.

description:
Every  time my bf and I are craving for some chowder and around the city we'd normally take a quick stop here to satisfy our cravings. 
Our last trip to the city (SF) last Tuesday, we got a pint of chowder and a dinner roll. Spent about $10 which isn't bad at all but this time, we took a closer look at the product. The chowder was too watery, had way too much potato instead of clams and it was boiling HOT! It took a while for the chowder to cool down and with the help of our dinner roll. 
We both agreed that the chowder would of been better if it was creamier and if it had more clams. I guess the next time we're craving for chowder we'll either drive else where or give the other stands a try.
author: MC C.

description: Growing up whenever we went to SF we always when to Guardinos for their clam chowder bread bowls so naturally when I returned to SF years later I went straight there and I have to say I was very disappointed.  I had their seafood combo sandwich and while the seafood was good I DID NOT like their tartar/mayo sauce.  Their Whole Crab & Clam Chowder may be good but I'll go elsewhere for a seafood sandwich.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Pssst...Hey you! Yeah you! Wanna learn a secret? I'm sure you do...You know that chowder you're eating? It comes from a can...Yeah, no shit! I speak the truth!

Before they came out with their own canned chowder with their name on a label on the can, we used to used canned clam chowder from somewhere...Not sure if it was Heinz or not...But I can guarantee you it came in a can. To make it taste less canned and more homemade, we would add potato flakes and dried parsley along with some water and dry non-dairy creamer. I am not shtting you, this is the truth. But if you taste it, you would never guess it came from a can unless we told you. Not sure how it works out that way. You can tell by looking at the chunks in the soup that it's canned. I mean, the potato chunks are all uniformly cut and the clams look the same way, too. And sometimes we tend to not stir the soup enough so some of the lumps from the mash mix will still be there...That's just us being sloppy and lazy. We're also human...But people always come back for more. Glad they enjoy it.

We also sold the normal fare like half lobsters and calamari salad and shrimp and crab cocktails. But we're the only place on the block that sells souvenirs. The inside shop used to be the old Guardino's mini restaurant. This was way back in the day. Before the Great Depression time. But eventually, they decided not to do that anymore and went the way of selling crap that tourists love to buy. San Francisco keychains, notebooks, sweatshirts, jackets, fleeces, just about anything you would expect a shop that caters to tourists. We also sold sea shells and sharks teeth and some other glass trinkets. Tons of stuff and it's very profitable...When they come in to buy. A lot of the time, the inside would be empty and the girls working inside would hate that because we would grab some of them and make them help us outside. They hate the smell and hate getting smelly from the outside but that's part of the job...It's written in invisible ink on the bottom of their application when they sign it.

I only worked here maybe a year before I moved down to Sabella and La Torre's. But there's no hard feelings there because it's all business. And burning bridges out here would not be good for me seeing as how close we are together on this one block of restaurants...

'eyyyyyyyy. Chowder!!! Get your hot chowder here! And fresh cracked crabs!
author: Anthony L.

description: I admit it.  I'm the oddball out.  I didn't order the chowdah.  Instead, I naively ordered the rather mediocre crab sandwich.  It was all right, but I think I would have been more satisfied had I hopped on the bandwagon with everyone else.  Lesson learned.  Tant pis.  Tant pis comme tourjours.
author: Jim D.

description: Very good chowder. I wanted to come back the next day and get it in a bowl (without the bread bowl). I tried chowder from 3 other places on/near the Warf, and this was the best.
author: Goose M.

description: The clam chowder is okay . Kind of salty and not creamy enough for my tastebuds. Tastes like it's from the canned clam chowders . The sourdough bread for the bread bowl is okay . Overall , nothing special .
author: Eileen L.

description:
What if you are tired, hungry, but running out of money after visiting Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco? You need a place of great food and rest with low price. Fortunately, there is. 
 I went to San Francisco with my friends last October, to spend our Fall Break vacation. I remember it was a clear day with typical California sunshine, when I had one of the most unforgettable memories in my life, eating Dungeness crabs at the Guardino Restaurant. 
As a matter of fact, instead of calling it a restaurant, I would rather say it is a booth. It located at 296 Jefferson Street, in the most bustling area of Fisherman's Wharf. It is a common knowledge that visiting San Francisco without tasting the famous "Dungeness Crabs" would be a huge mistake. San Francisco crabs are the best tasting and tenderest in the world. When my friends and I passed by the restaurant, we were attracted by a glass cabinet of Dungeness crabs. The crabs were so fresh and I could almost smell the scent of the sea. Although we didn't have much money left, we decided to try the food.
 The restaurant was very small, with only three tiny tables at the roadside. There was no waiter service so we needed to order from the vender by ourselves, which is one of the reasons why it's cheaper than other restaurants. 40 dollars will feed three people. Dungeness crabs are much bigger than normal crabs. It took about 15 minutes to wait until crabs are totally cooked. The chef cut the crabs into several parts before he carried them onto our table, so that we didn't have to use the pincer to divide the crabs. They were the best crabs I have ever tasted in my life. Without any sauce, we just enjoyed the original taste of the crabs, which was very fresh and delicious. 
 Not only was the food great, but so was the environment. With its sidewalk tables, the restaurant's atmosphere was that of the street: of Fisherman's Wharf. Numerous tourists passed by and greeted us, some stopping to ask, "Hey, what are you guys eating? Is it good?"  A short distance away from our seats, a band was playing jazz music and attracted quite a crowd. With the best crabs and best sunshine of California, the whole thing was fantastic.
  I strongly recommend you to go to Guardino Restaurant and enjoy the most relaxing moment and the best cuisine.
author: haiyi w.

description: It's not exactly a restaurant but in my opinion, it serves the GREATEST and BESTEST clam chowder in the world!!!  Its creamy and rich soup is served in a perfectly-soured Sourdough bread bowl.  The bread is so great that you don't need the crackers they give you to dip in the soup.  The pieces of meat in the chowder are so tasty, and the soup itself isn't too salty!!  Even if there are no chairs or tables, it's worth coming here.  Just cross the street and dig in under the Fisherman's Wharf sign!
author: Rinne R.

description:
We're regulars at this original stand at the Wharf and get our traditional fix of huge shrimp sandwiches: they're chockful of plump, t, fresh and crackly bay shrimp laced in a parsley and what tastes like a sour cream mayo dressing. 
Keep it up, Mike!
author: Sara K.

description: While I normally avoid tourist traps like Fisherman's Wharf, today we  stumbled upon Guardino's during an urban hike. The clam chowder was delicious! Even if it originates is a can like Anthony L. suggests, it's still great and worth the indulgence. Skip the bread bowl - the bread doesn't taste fresh and isn't worth the calories or the carbs. Just know that there's no seating available, so either be prepared to stand while you eat or look carefully before sitting on a pile of bird shit everywhere on the wharf.
author: Cher E.

description: Terrific Chowder -- and this from a native Bostonian. I just happened upon this place after doing some volunteer work nearby. Have to say I probably haven't been in Fisherman's wharf for some 20 years when my family first visited SF. I walked past the various vendors (Guardino's was the first) before coming back to Guardino's. Excellent choice. I got it in the cup without the bowl.
author: Patricia L.
